title: PJ Taylor - 2013 - A Pragmatic Realism - Events, Powers, and Rel
description: The early twentieth century witnessed the emergence of Ã¢â‚¬Å“objective relativism,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ a distinctly American school of metaphysical realism inspired by the works of John Dewey and A.N. Whitehead.  Largely forgotten, objective relativism provided a metaphysical framework, based upon an ontology of events and relations rather than substances and discrete properties, that has continued relevance for contemporary metaphysical discussions.  In this thesis, I attempt to chart the boundaries and pathways of this ontology, outlining what Dewey calls the Ã¢â‚¬Å“ground-map of the province of criticism.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½  In particular, the ground-map of objective relativism is invoked to situate and analyze the model of psycho-physical emergence outlined in DeweyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Experience and Nature.  Because it is a relational ontology, objective relativism avoids problems with emergence common to substantival models.  Additional analyses of its ontological premises, both in DeweyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s writings and elsewhere, demonstrate how compelling accounts of causation, consciousness, and meaning may be formulated within this model.
